snippet: Officials are seeking ways to exploit fissures between the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and groups that allied with it to seize much of northern and western Iraq.
abstract: American and Iraqi officials are seeking ways to exploit emerging fissures between Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and Iraqi extremist groups that allied with it to seize much of northern and western Iraq; marriages of convenience formed among ISIS and Baathists, Sunni nationalists, Sunni tribal groups and Sunni jihadists to fight Prime Min Nuri Kamal al-Maliki's government are coming under strain.

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and ALISSA J. RUBIN
byline.contributor: Eric Schmitt reported from Washington, and Alissa J. Rubin from Baghdad. Employees of The New York Times contributed reporting from Salahuddin, Diyala and Anbar Provinces.

lead_paragraph: Officials are seeking ways to exploit fissures between the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and groups that allied with it to seize much of northern and western Iraq.

headline.main: U.S. and Iraqis Try to Fragment Extremist Group
headline.print_headline: U.S. and Iraqis Try to Fragment Extremist Group
